--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Michael Gillam wrote:
> 
> >Hi Colin,
> >
> >Interesting post!
> >  
> >
> Thanks.
> 
> >Just to add a thought to the mix...
> >
> >One other possibility regarding consciousness is that it is an 
*emergent*
> >property of the network (i.e. not a necessary pursuit and not 
necessarily
> >real.)
> >  
> >
> I think a lot of mystery has been spun around the idea of 
conciousness 
> over the years. It is often (in books, documentaries, etc) 
discussed as 
> some intangible concept that is probably beyond the human mind to 
> comprehend. I often recall a sentence in 'Plan and Purpose In 
Nature' by 
> George Williams regarding early work on embyology:
> -----------
> The "intrinisc processes" of development so impressed the early 
pioneers 
> of experimental biology that many thought it obviously required 
> supernatural guidance.
> -----------
> 
> Although development in biology is still not even close to being 
fully 
> understood, we do understand some of the underlying principles 
that are 
> at work and it's quite inconceivable (to me anyway) to suggest 
that some 
> supernatural forces are at work. And yet this is precisely what 
some 
> have suggested is behind the phenomenon of conciousness. I'm going 
back 
> probably 10 years here but one case of this was Roger Penrose's 
book 
> Shadows Of The Mind in which he attempts to prove mathematically 
that 
> conciousness cannot be described by an algorithm. He then goes on 
to 
> suggest that neuron mitochondria may be somehow describing a much 
finer 
> (than relatively large neurons) information processing network 
that 
> operates at the quantum physical level, perhaps tapping into some 
> unknown physical dimension.
> 
> Now, while it's an interesting idea it was my interpretation that 
the 
> book was effectively saying that conciousness is something which 
is 
> supernatural and mysterious and it just feels like passing the 
buck to me.
> 

I know consciousness is very controversial, and also a bit off the 
NEAT trail, so to speak, but just to put in my 2 cents it's probably 
not fair to characterize the philosophical argument that 
consciousness is not a physical phenomenon as "supernatural."  It is 
not contradictory to a scientific view that some phenomenon are 
guided by rules and phenomena that are currently not characterized.  
That wouldn't make such phenomena any more supernatural than energy 
or mass, which once had not been characterized scientifically either.
Anyway, you make a valid point (and I don't mean to defend 
Penrose)..I'm just trying to say that calling one 
side "supernatural" makes the debate sound a lot less legitimate 
than I think it actually is.

> 
> This more abstract level of processing is what I reckon we would 
call 
> conciousnessness, although I do think that any system that senses 
it's 
> surrounding in some way in order to drive it's behaviour 
is 'concious' 
> to some degree. So I think a croc would percieve me as a pice of 
> possible prey, but it wouldn't percieve any fine detail such as, 
say, 
> the colour of my t-shirt :) (if they can even see in colour?). 
Taken to 
> an extreme a plankton is 'concious' of it's immediate surroundings 
and 
> my central heating thermostat is 'concious' of the temp in this 
room.
> 

Actually I don't think the consciousness debate is about abstract 
processing or awareness.  I don't think anyone serious on either 
side is claiming that abstract processing or awareness cannot be 
explained mechanistically or computationally.  Usually the "weird 
stuff" gets introduced when talking about phenomenal experience, 
i.e. qualia, which may well have nothing to do with level of 
intellect at all.  For that reason, I am betting that AI has a lot 
less to say about consciousness, at least the controversial aspects, 
than some people think.

ken
